content: Since 9/11, policymakers have been working to reduce the US vulnerability to terrorist use of weapons of mass destruction. This report discusses high-threat chemical agents, their availability, detection, and policy approaches to mitigate the threat. While the probability of terrorist use of chemical agents is low, the consequences could be severe. There is debate on whether terrorist groups are interested in acquiring and using chemical agents, but the US remains vulnerable to chemical attacks. Policy approaches have focused on reducing chemical vulnerability as a whole, rather than specific agents. Detection capabilities for military and civilian use vary, as do treatments for chemical exposure, which must be addressed on a case-by-case basis. Chemical exposure treatments vary depending on the type of chemical and must be addressed on a case-by-case basis. Limited practical experience in treating chemical casualties exists, especially among civilian healthcare providers. High-threat chemical agents pose exceptional lethality and danger to humans, with different symptoms and injuries caused by different chemical weapons. Identifying the specific chemical or type is crucial for determining the most effective treatment for victims. Chemical weapons may produce effects through different exposure routes. Chemical weapons can have different effects depending on the exposure route and type of chemical. Military planners categorize these agents into nerve, blister, choking, and blood agents based on the effects they cause. Nerve agents, like organophosphates, are manmade compounds with high toxicity and purity, primarily used as weapons. Nerve agents, such as Tabun, Sarin, and VX, were developed for military use in the 1930s and later by various countries like Germany, England, the United States, and the Soviet Union. These highly toxic liquids were used sparingly in conflicts, with reports of Iraq using them in the Iran-Iraq war and against Kurdish populations. Iraq used nerve agents against Iranian troops and Kurdish population. Nerve agents are highly toxic and can enter the body through the lungs or skin contact. VX is the most difficult to manufacture and the most deadly, causing overstimulation of muscles and potential death. Nerve agents can cause overstimulation of muscles, leading to symptoms like nausea, weakness, convulsions, and spasms. High concentrations can result in loss of muscle control, nervous system irregularities, and even death. Atropine and pralidoxime chloride are antidotes used to treat nerve agent exposure, with atropine preventing muscle spasms and pralidoxime chloride reversing the agent's effects. Treatment effectiveness depends on the specific nerve agent, with some requiring immediate intervention to prevent irreversible damage. Diazepam (Valium) may also be used to reduce convulsions and seizures from nerve agent exposure. Blister agents, such as mustard agents, cause painful blistering of the skin and require full body protection. Mustard agents were first developed in the late 1800s and evaporate quickly, with vapors also being injurious. These chemicals reduce combat effectiveness by necessitating bulky protective gear. Blister agents, like mustard agents, were first developed in the late 1800s and have been used in conflicts such as World War I and the Iran-Iraq war. Choking agents like chlorine, ammonia, and phosgene can cause breathing difficulties and permanent lung damage. Choking agents, such as chlorine, ammonia, and phosgene, are gases with strong odors and can cause breathing difficulties and permanent lung damage. They have been used in wartime and industrial accidents. Choking agents are dual-use chemicals with civilian and military applications, requiring specialized equipment for production. They were extensively used during World War I, with chlorine gas being the first major chemical attack. Exposure to choking agents primarily affects the respiratory system, causing chest discomfort and shortness of breath. Effects of choking agents include chest discomfort, shortness of breath, irritation of nose and throat, tearing eyes, lung swelling, respiratory failure, and potential death. Symptoms of lung damage may appear up to 48 hours after exposure. Treatment involves rest, oxygen supplementation, and corticosteroids for fluid accumulation in the lungs. Blood agents, such as hydrogen cyanide and cyanide salts, interfere with oxygen utilization at the cellular level. Hydrogen cyanide, a volatile gas with an almond smell, was used in chemical warfare and as the active agent in Zyklon B, the gas used in German concentration camps during World War II. It is now used in industrial applications in the chemical, electroplating, and mining industries. Physical protection against chemical agents includes gas masks and special clothing. Gas mask filters with activated charcoal are effective against inhaled chemical agents but may not fully protect against skin contact with certain agents. Gas mask filters are made of activated charcoal to remove particles and chemicals from the airstream. The filters have a limited lifetime based on the amount of activated charcoal remaining. Protective garments, such as hazardous materials suits, are made of rubber with activated charcoal for skin contact protection. Military battle dress overgarments are cloth with charcoal-impregnated foam for battlefield protection. The combination of mask and suit provides full protection against most chemical exposures. There are limited examples of medical prophylaxis against chemical weapons. Pyridostigmine bromide provides some protection against the nerve agent Soman by preventing permanent binding of nerve agents within the nervous system. It is recommended for use only in high imminent threat situations due to noticeable side effects. The U.S. Army Medical Research Institute of Chemical Defense has developed a chemical-resistant skin cream called SERPACWA to complement protective equipment for soldiers in the field. Decontamination is crucial for removing chemicals from victims to prevent secondary exposure and protect those treating the victims. It is especially important for victims exposed to liquid chemical agents. Treatment follows decontamination, with specific antidotes or symptomatic treatment.
